awd_titl_txt: MSU-ADVANCE Catalyst Project to Promote Gender Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
Missouri State University (MSU) will implement an ADVANCE Catalyst project to conduct an institutional self-assessment to understand the current status of women faculty in STEM disciplines on the main campus. This project will include a review of the current social and behavioral research on: gender equity, work-life balance, underrepresentation of certain groups in STEM, and organizational change. A central part of this project will be to undertake a comprehensive review of retention, promotion, and tenure (RPT) policies and related procedures and practices for each STEM department.  The project includes strategies to get direct input and advice from leaders of current and past ADVANCE institutions.

This two-year project will prepare the university for future data collection and data analyses of faculty equity which can be used by institutional leadership to inform decision-making.  The Catalyst work will also prepare the institution to implement evidence-based strategies to enhance the university climate for all faculty which will be outlined in a five-year faculty equity strategic plan that will be produced as part of this project.   

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Catalyst" awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Missouri State University (MSU) ADVANCE Catalyst Project was conducted during the period fall 2019 through summer 2022, and it involved twelve departments in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Science (STEM), across three academic colleges. Participating STEM departments are Biology, Chemistry & Biochemistry, Computer Science, Geology, Geography & Planning, Mathematics, Physics, Astronomy & Material Science, Anthropology & Sociology, Economics, History, and Political Science, Biomedical Sciences and Psychology The main outcomes of this self-assessment project are:

  1. (a) Collection and analysis of quantitative data covering the period 2007-2019, including new hires, gender representation, tenure and promotion reviews, years in rank, attrition, leadership positions, salaries and start-up packages. (b) Collection and analysis of qualitative data through focus groups conducted in 2020 to gain additional insight into possible gender inequities and to better understand the possible processes driving gender inequalities and inequities in STEM departments at MSU.
  2. Identification of three main barriers affecting women faculty in STEM on MSU campus: (a) Unequal hiring and representation, (b) Inequities in decisions regarding tenure and promotion to associate professor, (c) Less than inclusive climate and low sense of belonging.
  3. Piloting of equity strategies from fall 2021 to summer 2022, based on the findings above and on feedback received from six exemplary ADVANCE institutions.
  4. Development of a research-based, data-driven 5-year equity strategic plan to guide our future work on gender equity and systemic change.
  5. Development of a solid communication strategy to broadly communicate our efforts, accomplishments, and challenges with MSU campus and the community. This includes a dedicated website, social media engagement, participation at regional and national events related to gender equity, plans to establish an annual MSU-ADVANCE Conference to start in spring 2023, and continuous communication and collaboration with key support offices on campus.
  6. Establishment of three evidence-based equity strategies, built around identified barriers and aligned with our institution?s 2021-2026 Long Range Plan, to guide our work on equity for the next five years. They are: (1) Access: To improve women access to and representation in STEM departments; the main focus is on search committee trainings on diversity, intersectionality, and gender bias. (2) Success: To increase success of women STEM faculty in their applications for tenure and promotion to associate professor; the main focus is on tenure/promotion committee trainings in diversity, intersectionality, and gender bias, and on mentoring & networking initiatives to provide tenure-track faculty with the needed academic guidance and social support. (3) Climate and Education: To promote a more welcoming STEM climate and to increase STEM women faculty sense of belonging; the main focus is on department chairs training on the benefits of and initiatives for a welcoming departmental climate, and on facilitating campus-wide as well as cross-institutional networking opportunities for tenure-track faculty. These three strategies are adaptations of successful and institutionalized initiatives at two exemplary ADVANCE institutions, Iowa State and Michigan Tech, and they build on related existing initiatives on campus; the MSU ADVANCE team has been in continuous communication with ADVANCE leaders from those two institutions since fall 2020.
